title: 103_s1208
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Independence Hall Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall, were cared for by local government units before the Federal Government took over. Independence Hall, home to the Liberty Bell, was initially cared for by local government units before the National Park Service took over responsibility for preserving historic sites. However, financial constraints have hindered the Federal Government from meeting the capital needs of these sites in recent years. The Federal Government has struggled to meet the capital needs of historic sites like Independence Hall due to financial constraints. Minting a United States coin could help commemorate these buildings and support their maintenance and preservation for future generations. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 1,000,000 $1 silver coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition. The design will feature the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, symbolizing national shrines of liberty. Each coin will display its value and inscriptions. The $1 silver coins issued by the Secretary of the Treasury will feature the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, serving as symbols of national liberty. The coins will display their value, the year "1994", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins will be legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF THE COINS.

Coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at one US Mint facility. Minting can start 30 days after enactment for up to 1 year.

SEC. 7. SALE OF THE COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount as well. A surcharge of $7 per coin is required for all sales. SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods/services for this Act. Compliance with equal employment opportunity laws is still required. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. The Secretary collects surcharges from coin sales under this Act. 50% goes to the US Treasury to reduce the national debt, and 50% goes to the Independence Hall Preservation Fund for capital improvements and other needs at Independence National Historic Park. The Independence Hall Preservation Fund uses surcharges from coin sales to fund capital replacement projects and other needs at Independence National Historic Park to foster respect and admiration for the park. SEC. 10. The Comptroller General can audit the Independence Hall Preservation Fund's expenditure records. SEC. 11. Coins issued are subject to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 12. Financial assurances required. The Secretary must ensure no cost to the government for issuing coins authorized by this Act. Adequate security for payment is required before issuing any coin. The Secretary requires adequate security for payment before issuing any coin, which can be in the form of full payment or a guarantee from a depository institution with insured deposits.
